heading: 3 Homogeneous Function
text:
function \(f(x,y)\); can expressed writing \(x = kx\) \(y = ky\) form function \(f(kx,ky)= k^{n} f(x,y)\), constant \(k\) can taken \(n^{th}\) power exponent , called homogeneous function degree \(n\). \(n\) called degree homogeneity.Example 3.1: Verify \(f(x,y)\) homogeneous function.\(f(x,y) = x^{2} - 2xy\)
\(f(kx,ky) = (kx)^{2}- 2(kx)(ky)\)
= \(k^{2} x^{2} - 2k^{2}xy\)
= \(k^{2}(x^{2}- 2xy)\)
= \(k^{2} f(x,y)\)\(f(x,y) = x^{2} - 2xy\)\(f(kx,ky) = (kx)^{2}- 2(kx)(ky)\)
= \(k^{2} x^{2} - 2k^{2}xy\)
= \(k^{2}(x^{2}- 2xy)\)
= \(k^{2} f(x,y)\)Homogeneous function degree 2.\(f(x,y)= 3x+4y\)
\(f(kx,ky)= 3(kx)+4(ky)\)\(= 3kx+4ky\)\(= k(3x+4y)\)\(= k f(x,y)\)
Homogeneous function degree 1.\(f(x,y)= 3x+4y\)\(f(kx,ky)= 3(kx)+4(ky)\)\(= 3kx+4ky\)\(= k(3x+4y)\)\(= k f(x,y)\)Homogeneous function degree 1.\(f(x,y)= tan(x/y)\)
\(f(kx,ky)= tan(kx/ky)\)
\(= k^{0} tan(x/y)\)\(= k^{0} f(x,y)\)
Homogeneous function degree 0.\(f(x,y)= tan(x/y)\)\(f(kx,ky)= tan(kx/ky)\)\(= k^{0} tan(x/y)\)\(= k^{0} f(x,y)\)Homogeneous function degree 0.\(f(x,y)= x log y+ 5xy\)
\(f(kx,ky)=kx. log ky+ 5 kx. ky\)\(= kx. log y+ 5k^{2} xy\)
Homogeneous function\(f(x,y)= x log y+ 5xy\)\(f(kx,ky)=kx. log ky+ 5 kx. ky\)\(= kx. log y+ 5k^{2} xy\)Homogeneous function\(f(x,y)= 2 sin x+ cos y\)
\(f(kx,ky)=2 sin kx+ cos ky\)
Homogeneous function\(f(x,y)= 2 sin x+ cos y\)\(f(kx,ky)=2 sin kx+ cos ky\)Homogeneous functionProblem 3.1: Verify wether function homogenous\(f(x,y)= x^{3}+ 2x^{2}y- 3xy^{2} + y^{3}\)

heading: 3.1 Homogeneous differential equation
text: \(\frac{dy}{dx} = f(x,y)\) homogeneous differential equation \(f(x,y)\) homogeneous function.

heading: 3.2 Alternative definition of homogeneous function
text: function \(f(x,y)\) homogeneous function degree \(n\) can expressed formÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  \(f(x,y)= x^{n} g(y/x)\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  \(f(x,y)= y^{n} h(x/y)\)

heading: 3.2.1 Solving a homogeneous differential equation
text: Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  \(\frac{dy}{dx} = f(x,y)= g(y/x)\) Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (1)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  substitute \(y= vx\).Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  \(\frac{dy}{dx} = v+ x.\frac{dv}{dx}\) Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (2)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  substitute (2) (1)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  \(v+ x.\frac{dv}{dx} = g(v)\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  \(x.\frac{dv}{dx}= g(v)- v\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  \(\frac{dv}{g(v)-v} = \frac{dx}{x}\)can integrated find solution differential equation.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  \(\int\frac{dv}{g(v)-v} = -\int\frac{1}{x} dx+ c\)general solution obtained replacing back \(v= y/x\)

heading: 3.2.1.1 QUESTION 1.
text:
Find solution homogeneous differential equation\(dx (x^{2} + y^{2})= dy. 2xy\)SolutionÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  \(\frac{dy}{dx}= \frac{1+\frac{y^2}{x^2}}{2\frac{y}{x}}\) Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  ()Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  let \(y= vx\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  \(\frac{dy}{dx}= v+ x. \frac{dv}{dx}\) Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  (II)(II)Â ()Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(v + x\frac{dv}{dx} = \frac{1+\frac{v^2x^2}{x^2}}{2\frac{vx}{x}}\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(= \frac{1+v^2}{2v}\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(x\frac{dv}{dx} = \frac{1+v^2}{2v}-v\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 
\(= \frac{1+v^2-2v^2}{2v}\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 
\(= \frac{1-v^2}{2v}\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(\frac{2v}{1-v^2}dv = \frac{dx}{x}\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(\frac{2v}{v^2-1}dv = -\frac{dx}{x}\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(\int\frac{2v}{v^2-1}dv = -\int\frac{dx}{x}\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(log(v^2-1) = -logx+logc\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(log(v^2-1)+ logx = logc\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(log(v^2-1)x =logc\)Substituting \(v=y/x\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(log(\frac{y^2}{x^2}-1)x =logc\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(log(\frac {y^2-x^2}{x^2}x)=logc\)
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(log(\frac {y^2-x^2}{x})=logc\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(y^2-x^2=xc\)Solution differential equation :Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(y^2-x^2=xc\)

heading: 3.2.1.2 QUESTION 2.
text: Solve equation \(\frac{dy}{dx}= \frac{y(x-y)}{x^2}\)SolutionÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(\frac{dy}{dx}= \frac{yx}{x^2}-\frac{y^2}{x^2}\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â  Â  Â  Â \(= \frac{yx}{x^2}-(\frac{y}{x})^2\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(y =vx\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(v+x\frac{dv}{dx}=v-v^2\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(x\frac{dv}{dx}=-v^2\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(\implies -\frac{1}{v^2}dv=\frac{1}{x}dx\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(-\int\frac{1}{v^2}dv=\int\frac{1}{x}dx\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  \(\implies \frac{1}{v} =log(x)+log(c)=log(cx)\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(v= \frac{1}{log(cx)}\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(v=\frac{y}{x}\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(\frac{y}{x}= \frac{1}{log(cx)}\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(y= \frac{x}{log(cx)}\)

heading: 3.3 Eulerâ€™s theorem
text: Consider homogeneous function \(f\) \(x\), \(y\), \(z\),â€¦ degree \(n\), \(x\frac{df}{dx} + y\frac{df}{dy} + z\frac{df}{dz} + .... = nf\)

heading: 3.3.1 QUESTION 1.
text: Solve \(f = x^3 + y^3 + 3xy^2\)SolutionBy Eulerâ€™s theorem,\(x\frac{df}{dx} + y\frac{df}{dy} = nf\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(f(x,y)\) homogeneous function degree 3Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(\frac{df}{dx}= 3x^2 +3y^2\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(\frac{df}{dy}= 3y^2 +6xy\)NowÂ  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(x(3x^2+3y^2) +y(3y^2+6xy)\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(=3x^3+3xy^2+3y^3+6xy^2\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(=3x^3+3y^3+9xy^2\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(=3(x^3+y^3+3xy^2)\)Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â \(=3f(x,y)\)

heading: 4.2 Methods for finding the root
text:
methods finding roots \(f(x)=0\) classified asDirect methodsDirect methodsNumerical methodsNumerical methodsDirect methods give exact values roots finite number steps.Numerical methods based idea successive approximations. methods start one two initial approximations root obtain sequence approximations \(x_1,\)\(x_2,\),\(x_3,\),\(\cdots\)\(,x_k\) limit \(k\\infty\) exact root \(x=\).direct methods solving higher degree algebraic equations transcendental equations. equations can solved Numerical methods.theses methods, first find interval root lies. b two numbers f() f(b) opposite signs, root \(f(x)=0\) lies b. take b value b first approximation \(x_1\). improved numerical methods.Order convergence: iterative numerical method, successive iteration gives approximation moves progressively closer actual solution. known convergence. numerical method said order convergence \(ğœŒ\), \(ğœŒ\) largest positive number \(|ğœ–_{ğ‘›+1}|â‰¤{ğ‘˜}{|ğœ–_{ğ‘›}|}^ğœŒ\) , \(ğœ–_ğ‘›\) \(ğœ–_{ğ‘›+1}\) errors
\(ğ‘›^{ğ‘¡â„}\) \((ğ‘› + 1)^{ğ‘¡â„}\) iterations, \(ğ‘˜\) finite positive constant.

heading: 4.3.1 Bisection Method (or Bolzano Method)
text:
Bisection method used find approximate root interval repeatedly bisecting sub intervals. simple robust method also relatively slow. methods based intermediate value theorem continuous functions.
Figure 4.1: Figure showing Bisection method

heading: 4.3.1.1 Algorithm:
text:
Let \(ğ‘“(ğ‘¥)\) continuous function interval \(\left\lbrack ,b \right\rbrack\) \(\left.ğ‘“(ğ‘)\&\right.ğ‘“(ğ‘)\), \(ğ‘“(ğ‘)\) \(ğ‘“(ğ‘)\) opposite signs, .e.Â \({ğ‘“(ğ‘)ğ‘“(ğ‘)} < 0\), root \(f(x) = 0\) b.Step 1 : Let first approximation mid point interval \((,b)\). .e.,\[x_{1} = \frac{+ b}{2}\]\(f(x_1)= 0\), \(x_1\) root.\(f(x_1)= 0\), \(x_1\) root.Otherwise root lies \(\) \(x_1\) \(x_1\) \(b\) according

\(f(x_1)\) positive negative.bisect interval continue process 
root found desired accuracy.bisect interval continue process 
root found desired accuracy.Let \(f(x_1)\) positive, root lies \(\) \(x_1\), 
second approximation given ,Let \(f(x_1)\) positive, root lies \(\) \(x_1\), 
second approximation given ,\[x_{2} = \frac{+ \ x_{1}}{2}\]Let \(f(x_2)\) positive, root lies \(\) \(x_1\), 
second approximation given ,\[x_{3} = \frac{x_{2} + \ x_{1}}{2}\]Similarly, get approximations.Remarks:Convergence unidirectional none end points fixed. result convergence Bisection method slow.Convergence unidirectional none end points fixed. result convergence Bisection method slow.Repeating procedure ğ‘› times, new interval exactly half length previous one, root found desired accuracy (error less âˆˆ). Therefore end \(ğ‘›^{ğ‘¡â„}\) iteration, interval containing root length \(\frac{|b-|}{2^n}\), \(\frac{|b-|}{2^n}|<âˆˆ\)
â‡’ \(\log\frac{|b-|}{2^n}|<âˆˆ\)
â‡’ \(\log{|ğ‘ âˆ’ ğ‘|}âˆ’ log {2^ğ‘›}< log âˆˆ\)
â‡’ \(\log{|ğ‘ âˆ’ ğ‘|}âˆ’ log âˆˆ < n log 2\)
â‡’ \(ğ‘› > \frac{log |ğ‘âˆ’ğ‘|âˆ’log âˆˆ}{log2}\)Repeating procedure ğ‘› times, new interval exactly half length previous one, root found desired accuracy (error less âˆˆ). Therefore end \(ğ‘›^{ğ‘¡â„}\) iteration, interval containing root length \(\frac{|b-|}{2^n}\), \(\frac{|b-|}{2^n}|<âˆˆ\)
â‡’ \(\log\frac{|b-|}{2^n}|<âˆˆ\)

heading: 4.3.2 Regular False Method
text:
Figure 4.2: Figure showing Regular False method
Regula-Falsi method also known method false position false position curve taken initial approximation. Let \(y=f(x)\) represented curve AB. real root equation \(f(x) = 0\) Î± shown figure. false position curve AB taken chord AB initial approximation x_1 point intersection chord AB x-axis. Successive approximations x2, x3, â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦.. given point intersection chord â€™B, â€B,â€¦â€¦. x-axis, root found desired accuracy.Now equation chord AB two-point form given :
\[{ğ‘¦ âˆ’ ğ‘“(ğ‘)}= \frac{ğ‘“(ğ‘)âˆ’ğ‘“(ğ‘)}{b-}{(ğ‘¥ âˆ’ ğ‘)}\]find \(ğ‘¥_1\) (point intersection chord AB ğ‘¥ - axis), put ğ‘¦=0â‡’ \[âˆ’ğ‘“(ğ‘) = \frac{ğ‘“(ğ‘)âˆ’ğ‘“(ğ‘)}{b-}{(ğ‘¥_{1}âˆ’ ğ‘)}\]
â‡’ \[\frac{-f()(b-)}{f(b)-f()}=(x_1-)\]
â‡’ \[(x_1âˆ’) = \frac{âˆ’(ğ‘âˆ’ğ‘)ğ‘“(ğ‘)}{f(b)-f()}\]
â‡’ \[ x_1 = -\frac{(b-)f()}{f(b)-f()}\]Repeat procedure root found desired accuracy.Remarks:Rate convergence much faster bisection method.Rate convergence much faster bisection method.Unlike bisection method, one end point converge actual root ğ‘, whereas end point always remains fixed. result Regula- Falsi method linear convergence.Unlike bisection method, one end point converge actual root ğ‘, whereas end point always remains fixed. result Regula- Falsi method linear convergence.

heading: 4.3.2.1 Examples
text:
Example 1Apply Regula Falsi method find root equation \(x^3+x-1=0\) correct two decimal places.Solution:
\[ğ‘“(ğ‘¥) = ğ‘¥^{3} + ğ‘¥ âˆ’ 1\]\(ğ‘“(0) = âˆ’1\) \(ğ‘“(1) = 1\) â‡’ \(ğ‘“(0). ğ‘“(1)< 0\)Also ğ‘“(ğ‘¥)continuous \(\left\lbrack 0,1 \right\rbrack\),
âˆ´ atleast one root exists \(\left\lbrack 0,1 \right\rbrack\)Initial approximation\[x_{0} = - \ \frac{(b - )}{f(b) - f()}\ f()\]= 0, b=1\({ x}_{0} = 0 - \frac{(1 - 0)}{f(1) - f(0)}\ f(0) = 0.5\)\(f(0.5) = -0.375\), \(f(0.5).f(1)<0\)First approximationa = 0.5, b=1\({x}_{1} = 0.5 - \frac{(1 - 0.5)}{f(1) - f(0.5)}\ f(0.5)= 0.636\)\(f(0.636) = -0.107\), \(f(0.636).f(1) <0\)Second approximationa = 0.636, b=1\({x}_{2} = 0.636 - \frac{(1 - 0.636)}{f(1) - f(0.636)}\ f(0.636)= 0.6711\)\(f(0.6711) = -0.0267\), \(f(0.6711).f(1)<0\)Third approximationa = 0.6711, b=1\({ x}_{3} = 0.6711 - \frac{(1 - 0.6711)}{f(1) - f(0.6711)}\ f(0.6711)= 0.6796\)First 2 decimal places stabilized, hence 0.6796 real root correct two decimal placesExample 2Determine root equation \(\cos{x - \ e^{x}}= 0\) method False position correct two decimal places.Solution:\(f(x) = cos x-xe^x\)\(f(0) = cos 0-0e^{0}=1\)
\(f(1) = cos 1-1e^{1}= -2.177979523\)= 0 b = 1, root lies 0 1\(x_1= 0.3146653378\)\(f(x_1) = f(0.314653378) = 0.51986\)Therefore, root lies 0.314653378 1\(x_2= 0.44673\)Similarly,\(x_3= 0.49402\)\(x_4= 0.50995\)\(x_5= 0.51520\)\(x_6= 0.51692\)First 2 decimal places stabilized, hence 0.51692 real root correct two decimal place

heading: 4.3.3 Newton Raphson Method
text:
another important method. method named Isaac Newton Joseph Raphson powerful technique solving equations numerically.Let \(x_0\) approximation root \(f(x)=0\). Let \(x_1=x_0+h\) correct root \(f(x_1)=0\). Expanding \(f(x_1) = f(x_0+h)\) Taylor
series, get,\(f(x_1) = f(x_0+h) = f(x_0) + h f'(x_0) +\frac{h^{2}}{2!}f"(x~0~)+\cdots= 0\)small values h, neglecting terms \(h^2\), \(h^3\),\(\cdots\) get,\[f(x_0) + h f'(x_0) = 0\]\(h =\frac{- f(x_{0})}{f^{'}(x_{0})}\)\(x_1~= x_0+h\)\(= x_0-\frac{f(x_{0})}{f'(x_{0})}\)Proceeding like , successive approximation \(x_2, x_3,\cdots,x_{n+1}\) given ,\({x}_{n + 1} = \ x_{n}\ â€“\ \frac{f(x_{n})}{f^{'}(x_{n})}\) \(n=0,1,2,.....\)Remarks:Netwon-Raphson method can used solving algebraic transcendental equations can alsobe used roots complex.Netwon-Raphson method can used solving algebraic transcendental equations can alsobe used roots complex.Initial approximation x0 can taken randomly interval
\(\left\lbrack ,b \right\rbrack\), \(f().f(b)<0\)Initial approximation x0 can taken randomly interval
\(\left\lbrack ,b \right\rbrack\), \(f().f(b)<0\)Newton-Raphson method quadratic convergence, case bad choice \(x_0\), Newton Raphson method may fail converge.Newton-Raphson method quadratic convergence, case bad choice \(x_0\), Newton Raphson method may fail converge.method useful case large value \(f^{'}(x_{n})\) .e, graph \(f(x)\) crossing x-axis nearly vertical.method useful case large value \(f^{'}(x_{n})\) .e, graph \(f(x)\) crossing x-axis nearly vertical.

heading: 4.3.3.1 Examples
text:
Example 1Use Newton Raphson method find root equation \(x^{3} - 5x + 3 = 0\) correct three decimal places.Solution\(f(x) = x^{3\ } - 5x + 3\)\(f^{'}(x) = 3x^{2\ } - 5\)\(f(0) = 3\)
\(f(1) = -1\)\(f(0).f(1)<0\)Also f(x) continuous \(\left\lbrack 0,1 \right\rbrack\).Therefore atleast one root exists \(\left\lbrack 0,1 \right\rbrack\).Initial approximationLet initial approximation \((x_0)\) interval \(\left\lbrack 0,1 \right\rbrack\) 0.8By Newton-Raphson method
\[x_{n + 1\ } = x_{n} - \ \frac{f(x_{n})}{f^{'}(x_{n})}\]First approximation\(x_{1}= x_{0} - \ \frac{f\left( x_{0} \right)}{f^{'}\left( x_{0} \right)}\) ,\(x_0 = 0.8\)\(f\left( x_{0} \right) = f(0.8) = - 0.488\)
\(f'\left( x_{0} \right) = f'(0.8) = - 3.08\)\(x_{1} = 0.8 - \ \frac{- 0.488}{- 3.08} = 0.6416\)Second approximation\(x_{2} = x_{1} - \frac{f(x_{1})}{f^{'}(x_{1})}\) , \(x_1= 0.6415\)\(f\left( x_{1} \right) = f(0.6416) = 0.0561\)
\(f'\left( x_{1} \right) = f(0.6416) = - 3.7650\)\(x_{2} = 0.6416 - \ \frac{0.0561}{- 3.7650}= 0.6565\)Third approximation\(x_{3} = x_{2} - \frac{f(x_{2})}{f^{'}(x_{2})}\) , \(x_2= 0.6565\)\(f\left( x_{2} \right) = f(0.6565) = 0.0004\)
\(f'\left( x_{2} \right) = f(0.6565) = - 3.7070\)\(x_{3} = 0.6565 - \ \frac{0.0004}{- 3.7070}= 0.6566\)Hence root equation \(x^{3} - 5x + 3 = 0\ \)correct three decimal places 0.6566.Example 2Find approximate value \(\sqrt{28}\) correct three decimal places using Newton Raphson methodSolution\[x = \sqrt{28}\]\[x^{2\ } - 28 = 0\]\(f(x) = x^{2\ } - 28\)\[f^{'}(x) = 2x\]\(f(5) = -3\)
\(f(6) = 8\)\(f(5).f(6)<0\)Also f(x) continuous \(\left\lbrack 5,6 \right\rbrack\)Therefore atleast one root exists \(\left\lbrack 5,6 \right\rbrack\)Initial approximationLet initial approximation \((x_0)\) interval \(\left\lbrack 5,6 \right\rbrack\) 5.5By Newton-Raphson method,\(x_{n + 1\ } = x_{n} - \ \frac{f(x_{n})}{f^{'}(x_{n})}\)First approximation\(x_{1} = x_{0} - \ \frac{f\left( x_{0} \right)}{f^{'}\left( x_{0} \right)}\) ,\(x_0 = 5.5\)\(f\left( x_{0} \right) = f(5.5) = 2.25\)
\(f'\left( x_{0} \right) = f'(5.5) = 11\)\(x_{1} = 5.5 - \frac{2.25}{11}= 5.2955\)Second approximation\(x_{2} = x_{1} - \frac{f(x_{1})}{f^{'}(x_{1})}\) , \(x_1= 5.2955\)
\(f\left( x_{1} \right) = f(5.2955) = 0.0423\)
\(f'\left( x_{1} \right) = f(5.2955) = 10.591\)\(x_{2} = 5.2955 - \ \frac{0.0423}{10.591}= 5.2915\)Third approximation\(x_{3} = x_{2} - \frac{f(x_{2})}{f^{'}(x_{2})}\) , \(x_2= 5.2915\)\(f\left( x_{2} \right) = f(5.2915) = - 0.00003\)
\(f'\left( x_{2} \right) = f(5.2915) = 10.583\)\(x_{3} = 5.2915 - \frac{- 0.00003}{10.583}= 5.2915\)Hence value \(\sqrt{28}\) correct three decimal places 5.2915.

heading: 4.3.4 Generalized Newtonâ€™s Method for Multiple Roots
text:
Result: \(ğ›¼\) root equation \(ğ‘“(ğ‘¥) =0\) multiplicity ğ‘š, also root equation \(ğ‘“â€²(ğ‘¥) =0\) multiplicity (ğ‘šâˆ’1) also equation \(ğ‘“â€²â€²(ğ‘¥) =0\) multiplicity (ğ‘šâˆ’1) .example:\((ğ‘¥âˆ’1)^3= 0\) â€˜1â€™ root multiplicity 3\(3(ğ‘¥âˆ’1)^2 = 0\) â€˜1â€™ root multiplicity 2\(6(ğ‘¥âˆ’1) = 0\) â€˜1â€™ root multiplicity 1âˆ´ expressions \(x_{n} - \ m\frac{f(x_{n})}{f^{'}(x_{n})},\)
\(x_{n} - \ (m - 1)\frac{f'(x_{n})}{f^{''}(x_{n})},\) \(x_{n} - \ (m - 2)\frac{f''(x_{n})}{f^{'''}(x_{n})}\) equivalent.Generalized Newtonâ€™s method used find repeated roots equation given :\(ğ›¼\) root equation \(ğ‘“(ğ‘¥) =0\) repeated ğ‘š times,
\({x_{n + 1} = \ x_{n} - m\frac{f(x_{n})}{f^{'}(x_{n})}}_{}\sim\ x_{n} - \ (m - 1)\frac{f'(x_{n})}{f^{''}(x_{n})}\)
